Text:
Having received word from John Smith, Yukime awaits
his arrival.
Not long after he arrives, the train departs.
This single gold coin can double many times over...
However...

All on the back of the fickle, phantasmal power
called credit...
...Are you referring to bills?

The slips of paper that the masses think of as
currency aren't technically money at all.

In truth, they're deposit slips to retrieve money
you've lent the bank, nothing more.

Let's say, hypothetically, that someone deposits
10,000 zeni in the bank.

The bank will then issue the depositor a 10,000 zeni
bill, which they can then use for their shopping.

Yukime mulls over the fact that Mitsugoshi Bank
considers having convinced people their deposit
slips were just as good as money to be their
magnum opus.
But something strange happens here.
There's the 10,000 stored at the bank...
...and the 10,000 deposit slip.
All of a sudden there's 20,000 zeni floating around.

Now, if all the bank did was let the original 10,000
zeni sit quietly in their vault, there wouldn't be a
problem.

Even if the money in the system still technically
doubled, the amount out in the marketplace is still
just 10,000 zeni, so no contradiction is born.

However, the bank's been using the 10,000 zeni they
received as collateral...
...to lend out more bills.

The economic boom in the capital began with
Mitsugoshi's business initiatives. Not wanting
to be left behind, merchants sought financing,
leading the bank to issue bills…

Nobody wants to walk around with a heavy sack of
gold coins. Despite many not fully grasping their
value, the use of bills is rapidly increasing.

The 10,000 zeni in their vault multiplies countless
times over, and thanks to the capital's economic
boom, Mitsugoshi Bank gets to rake in the interest.
Such is the true power of "credit creation"!
"Credit creation"... That's a fitting way to describe it.

Using this scheme to assign a slip of paper worth
less than a copper coin, a value greater than gold...
The head of Mitsugoshi Bank must be quite the con artist.

I would love to have a chat with such an individual
if I ever get the chance.
Heh...

But are these slips of paper really as valuable as
the people believe they are?
John Smith hands her two bills.

One is Mitsugoshi's. The other is the MCA's.
Notice anything?

The designs are different, of course, but she doubts
that that's what he's hinting at.
In that case...
One has a watermark, while the other does not?
Exactly.

Also, the MCA's design is more simplistic, as is the
printing and cutting.
Do you know what that means?
...It's easier to make counterfeits?
*grin*
We could make a killing off counterfeit bills.

Making counterfeits is an idea even a child could
come up with. Yukime has certainly considered the
possibility, and there is no doubt that the MCA has
as well.
Um...Mr. Smith?

I'm sure you've realized this, but the MCA's bills
have yet to circulate outside the capital.

Any counterfeits would be instantly traced back to
their source.
Wha—?!

A small-scale operation might be possible, but the
profits would be correspondingly minor, mind you.
What are your thoughts on that?
John Smith's shoulders slump dejectedly.

He looks like a child who, upon asking a friend to go
treasure hunting with him, was given the perfectly
logical response that there was no treasure to be
found.

He wasn't seriously planning on making counterfeits,
was he? Yukime thinks the man has a surprisingly cute
side to him too.

At this rate, Mitsugoshi is liable to gain a complete
stranglehold on all commercial and banking
operations. Just as Yukime begins contemplating
countermeasures—
Wha—?!
Really?
Is that really what you believe?
What's with this pressure?

It's not even magic. It's like his willpower given
form— It's almost as though he's saying Yukime's
judgment was flawed.

He's testing her. To see whether or not she's fit to
be his partner...!
But still... What was it she overlooked?
Such is the true power of "credit creation".
...It can't be!

If we were to suddenly flood the market with a huge
number of counterfeit notes, they'd be discovered, of
course. And soon, rumors would reach the citizens...

And once they begin harboring suspicions about the
value of their own money, their trust in bills...
...will be lost!
At that moment, John Smith's eyes open wide.

Anticipating—no, ensuring the counterfeits are
discovered is what's essential!

Once people start questioning their money's value,
they'll rush to the banks to exchange their bills for
gold coins...

By anticipating this, we can corner the market and
rake in profits!
So that's what you meant!

The shorter the time before the MCA went bankrupt,
the lower the risk of them getting caught. Better
yet, Yukime has access to the perfect front—the
Lawless City.

If they circulate the currency through the Lawless
City, it will take much longer to pin down where the
counterfeits are coming from. By the time the MCA
figures out the truth, it will be too late.
To think he thought all that through.

Yukime finally realizes why he slumped his shoulders
a moment ago. He'd been disappointed in her.

Disappointed in her for not realizing the true
significance of the counterfeits. He had been
testing her. He definitely hadn't proposed
making counterfeits on some idle whim.

It had been a calculated decree. He'd left nothing to
chance.
Really?
Is that...really what you believe...?
The aura radiating from John Smith intensifies.

Yukime frantically racks her brain, but she comes up
blank.
...It is.
The plan...is airtight.
Exactly...

(The final thing he'd been testing had been my
honesty...)

(If I'd given in to the pressure and spouted some
nonsense—)
(John Smith... The man once called Shadow...)

What unbelievable ingenuity. What unbelievable grit.
What unbelievable strength.

Originally, Yukime wanted to win him over for his
strength alone, but the man is blessed with far more
than just martial prowess.
Truly, he is a giant among men...
